I really feel for everyone in this doc. I've been impoverished and desperate myself (hitchhiking 26 miles to work every day, 36 cents in my bank account, dodging the landlord etc) It's pure misery that leaves you with something akin to post traumatic stress. However, I can't help but think that a teeny bit of honesty might be missing from this piece. It is true that the system is impersonal and merciless and downright Kafkaesque at times...but I also think it's very hard for most people to own up to the full folly of their choices.

Spending more than you make (whether bad luck of medical issues, or something else) results in a tough life, no doubt about it. Subjecting yourself to these fees on top of it all is just crazy. On top of that, wanting loans and credit isn't the solution either.  The "rub" in this film is that none of these people were forced to take on these loans, they chose to do so. What was their alternative? Bankruptcy? Negotiating payment plans? Charity? etc.
The system is rigged.

I hear ya. I have 2 prescriptions I have to fill for myself every month. One of them is $45 and the other is $2,900 if I didn't have health insurance & if I stop taking the expensive one, I will likely die in less than a week (luckily for me I have wealthy parents who have agreed to chip in to pay for it if something happened so that fact doesn't stress me out as much as it would the average person who, if they lost their job, would be unable to pay for it in a short period of time). My husband has 4 prescriptions every month & those add up to about $200, My stepson's 2 perscriptions are $350 a month, My oldest daughter has asthma so it's $75 a month for her one inhaler & my youngest daughter has severe allergies so her couple meds are about $175 a month.   We pay $1,500 a month for our health insurance plan every month but have a deductible of $3,000 per person and/or $6,000 per family. Every time you go to the clinic or hospital there is at least $50 for a co-pay & a hospital is $150 for a co-pay. We pay about $24,000 a year in health care costs because after the family pays the $6,000 deductible, the insurance company pays the rest however we still pay $1,500 a month for that "privilege". Basically what all this means is my family of 5 gets screwed (My husband, me, 2 daughters & 1 son) & everyone else gets rich (drug companies, hospitals, health insurance companies, pharmacies, doctors, specialists & the politicians who set up this system so a select few get rich off of everyone else.). We live in one of the richest countries in the world but the priorities of the 1% who are allowed to dump huge amounts of money into our political system, are to get as much money as they can from everyone else. The above info I provided is what an average "middle class" family is responsible for to get health care. I really wish we had a system that was more like every other developed nation has. In this country it's actually against the law (thanks to "campaign contributions" from the drug companies to our politicians) for the government to negotiate to get better drug prices for the people on medicare (which is the government run health care plan for the elderly & disabled) & if that doesn't show you how completely off track we have gotten here, nothing will. If you don't want to be like these people: - Don't buy a house when you can't afford it. Just rent. - Don't take out payday loans, if you really need advanced money, sell some useless possessions you have. Then, you should have enough money until payday. - Don't buy anything you don't need. You only need a cheap phone plan, a cheap computer and cheap internet, cable, TVs, fancy computers are useless.¬† - If you only drive in the city, sell your car and buy something cheaper and better on gas. - Don't borrow money that you know you won't be able to pay back. - If you can't find a job, move to a city with more jobs, a lot of cities have great economies (if you have enough money to go to a few movies, and buy a bunch of useless shit, you can afford to move) - If you don't like the US, nobody is forcing you to stay there, you can move at any time. - Put your children's future ahead of your parents. Sorry, but if your parents are dying of cancer, quitting work to look after them won't bring them back to life. They are old and they will only live a few more years even if they survive. If you quit, your child may have to live in poverty until they finally finish college, maybe even their whole life.

Simple ways to save money no matter where in the world you live!  - Walk, bicycle, use public transportation instead of a car. A car costs more to have if you don't have money. It may not be the thing you want but you'll probably have to consider to get rid of it.  - Don't buy stuff you don't really need. This includes snacks, soda, alcohol, candy etc. If you cannot get by, cutting down on these will help a lot. It may be lonely on a weekend without something, but you'll sleep good knowing you're not in debt.  - Turn off all electronics when you're not using them(i.e away from home). This includes the power led on your TV, stereo etc. Don't leave your computer running when you're not at home. Also make sure you don't have any lamps running.  - Switch out those old lamps for energy saving ones. Their life expectancy is generally higher and you'll save money on the electric bill in the long run.  - Make a list of groceries you need and if you can, buy them from day to day. This ensures, if you live fairly close to a convenient store, that you don't have to throw away stuff you may not eat. If you live far away, carefully planning your run to the store and what you need to buy, is far better than going in there blind. This saves money!  While you do all this your health may improve as well, as you're active a lot more than before. Now you eat and buy only what you need and can afford to put the little money you have over into savings for a rainy day or a treat.  I understand what it's like to not have much, it's not fun and can be frustrating to not be able to treat yourself with something now and then. But when you don't have any money, it's time to let go of self indulgence and think smart.  Hope these few tips helped someone in need out there.  Cheers!  Another thing I came to think of, this probably will hurt the most, but it's one of those things that will help you get by, financially, easier. If you own a pet, letting it go may be the right thing to do. Maybe ask a relative to take care of it until you get back on your feet.

I, as a Dutchman, have lived in the states myself and have an American girlfriend, so I have personally experienced some of the differences in terms of banking. E.g. at home I don't remember seeing anyone write out a check in my lifetime (25)¬†, where as I have American friends my age who use them to this day.Regardless I'm still quite shocked by the systems explained in this documentary.. In case anyone is interested allow me to summarize this from the Dutch perspective. It isn't perfect either but it does seem more practical and even fair (as far as basic access/utility of banking goes). If you are bored already please save yourself the TL;DR effort ;)  So I live in the Netherlands. In order to have a private bank account as a non student, you pay an estimated ‚Ç¨1,75 to ‚Ç¨5 of a service fee per month, depending on the bank of your choice. The primary banking card used in the Netherlands is an ATM/debit card, Credit Cards have always been a secondary choice for the Dutch though it is growing in popularity largely due to traveling and non-Dutch online stores which don't include a debit card payment option. Paying with a Debit card in a store, or making digital transactions through the banks internet banking environment (which every bank has) is free/included in the above mentioned service fee and possible through your smart phone or your web browser. If I'mm not mistaken, in order to get a bank account in the Netherlands, all you need is to be a Dutch citizen or have a valid visa/social security number. If ¬†you can demonstrate a steady income (1 salary transfer is generally enough) you can increase your limit depending on your income. As an example I could set my limit to minus ‚Ç¨1000,- (max=monthly salary) which won't cost anything as long as you maintain a positive balance. If however you dip below ‚Ç¨0 you will have to make sure you top off your bank account back to 0 and pay the interest over the amount you 'borrowed' for the duration that you did. These interest rates are relatively high (~12-15%), but after all debt should be avoided where possible so some discouragement is probably warranted.¬†

My heart goes out to these people, but even with the bumps of life, their situations were preventable. Let's see how, starting at age 17:  1) Go to a local community college. In most states a 2 year degree fulfills core requirements and can transfer to a 4 year school. Take a credit load that's not too heavy and work full time. Live with your parents and save every penny you can.  2) Transfer to a 4 year school, but do your last 2 years over 3-4, part time, pay as you go and work a full time job  3) In this time, get a checking account and keep a solid minimum in there. Get a FingerHut account to buy holidat gifts as well as birthday gifts, apply for their credit, pay it off in full before due date  4) Graduate college. Get a full time job or advance in your existing one. Save up and purchase a used car  5) Apply for credit with a store like Value City Furniture. Get 12 months terms, get your basic furniture, and pay twice the minimum before the due date  6) NEVER pay your utilities late. Ever. Use only a cell phone, look for apartments with free heat, don't leave TV/Computers?lights on 24/7  7) Start a savings account. Get a 401k through work, but on your own open a savings account and each paycheck pay in until you save 6 months expenses  8) Get a credit card. set a budget for entertainment (restaurants, movies, etc) per week and pay with the card. Pay the abalance in full, each month, BEFORE the due date. By now you have a PERFECT FICO of 850  9) Don't marry anyone with a FICO under 600, and no debt that will take them more than a year to pay off  10) Get your partner's debt paid off before marrying  11) Share an apartment, apply for a car loan for a new car (not expensive) and pay it in full or more before the due date.  12) Consult with a financial advisor on a mortgage you can actually afford. DO NOT SPEND A PENNY MORE  13) Bump up your 6 months savings while house shopping  14) Buy a house, keep up on the mortgage, pay the balance due every month before due date or on due date  15) Once savings is accumulated, consult financial advisor on when you can afford a child. Sat a new savings for their college expenses  If everyone did this, there would be no payday or car title loans, no crippling debt. Do this and you have perfect credit, a newer car, a house, a responsible spouse, emergency funds, and a plan for the future.  WHY THE FUCK IS THIS SO HARD< AMERICANS?

I see a lot of "stop buying stuff" and "they just made bad financial decisions". Seriously? I actually don't like how the emphasis was on credit in this either. It comes down to very low paying jobs at the bottom of society. I know couples with full time/overtime jobs that still have to budget small things just to pay the bills. The price of everything has gone up over the years yet ppl get paid the same wage. 15 dollars an hour is considered good and a job ppl are jealous of. Someone with a full time even 20$ an hour job would struggle to pay for an apartment/gas/food/bills etc. I don't want to start a minimum wage argument either but min wage is barely enough to buy milk and bread. A long time ago you could have a single income household/stay at home mom scenario and still live comfortably with vacations every year. There is zero chance of this happening today in the real world. I get financial decisions could be better but don't blindly blame these ppl and act like the system is fine the way it is. Havn't even mentioned the health issues ppl run into either. Even if you and your spouse do wanna work 2 jobs each and "earn" that house/vacation every year... you better find a babysitter because daycare can cost you a good bit of that money you're trying to earn. There's also the random "rock cracked my windshield... need a new one" or "water heater gave out... need a new one" things that happen all the time in life. There just isn't enough money to go around.

I am not an American and live in a developing country, though someday I aspire to be one. After watching this entire documentary, I've come to notice a few important aspects, though I may just be looking at it as a non-American. Nevertheless, allow me to list them out here. All of the people shown in this video except for the couple who're looking for a new house, live in houses that are huge and can easily accommodate multiple families besides themselves. About half of them are slightly edging towards the overweight scale of normality which is probably an indication of why money falls short. If groceries are going to hike your expenses, alongwith a huge house and its supplementary costs (power, water, other utilities). I noticed in one of the shots that Debii (the entrepreneur), had a Starbucks coffee on the table besides her. Ironically, it was the same scene where she was scrambling for money. Not that people shouldn't drink coffee or anything but coming from a country where Starbucks has negligible business, I can't help but look at it with a little skepticism (after all, Starbucks costs about 2$ around here whereas the actual production cost is about 20-30% of that amount).  Not a troll, just wondering

My Mother once had a Sear's Charge account. I always believed that it was low enough for us to easily pay off, I was wrong, it was over $2,000's. I was so disgusted that not only had she miss lead her own child but no matter what I did to give her a way to get rid of the debt she stopped listening to me. So one day she mentioned something, she had been paying on a life insurance policy from my late Grandfather, her Father, for years which he had got for her, but my Grandmother, her mother, had recently given us both policies, and she said to me I'm going to see if I can close the policy account, I don't need it I have another. The policy cash payout was what we needed and I had the power to do what I needed to do. I made her take the cash pay out and got rid of that Sear's Charge account in one huge payment, we were free. In Germany you pay income tax up to 42%, 5.5%solidarity tax, 17,5% health care, 3% unemployment insurance, 19% Retirement insurance. Partially this is payed by the employer, but all in all my wife and i pay around 50% in taxes and obligatory insurances. Additionally everything has 19% VAT. Some of these comments make it seem like you don't have any kids, never been sick, never known anybody with kids or illnesses. Stuff happens- for the most part, the people in this video could afford all the things they were paying for until something bad hit them. While it is smart to plan for disasters, you cannot possibly know the financial hit you will take until you get hit. My brother-in-law came from the school of thought that he'd never been sick, young guy, 35 years old, no kids, very well educated, an amazing artist and his knack was tattooing. He faced an armed robbery one night in his shop- the one night he wasn't packing heat, mind you, and wound up emotionally scarred from that ordeal so he went back to bartending.¬† He didn't have any insurance because remember, he'd never been sick and didn't have any kids, lived in an apartment he could afford ten times over. Thought he had appendicitis- went to the E.R.- full blown liver failure, he could have died that night. The hospital 'charitied' out the hospital room fee which was $60,000- the fees for the doctors and services have gone well over $200k. He is tattooed from his chin to his feet so there is a good bet that he will never have a 'normal' job- tattooing and bartending are out because even a drop of alcohol could kill him, cigarettes too. Were his choices poor? Maybe. But which ones? The drinking? Or being so heavily tattooed? He didn't have kids, didn't spend beyond his means, no student loans- all the things you all have listed as being poor choices. I don't know what the answers are in terms of falling into financial ruin and getting up out of it but walk a mile in the shoes of another and look in the mirror. Have I listed anything that you have done or currently do? Are you suggesting that people just not live their lives under the aegis that they 'might' get sick or be laid off? Think about that the next time you spend a dollar or ten on something completely frivolous just because it feels good- and then stop what you're doing and go on being miserable.

"Don't Cry Over Spilled Milk", You'll Be There All Day!  My comments to the YouTube Video: "SPENT: Looking For Change" My Classification: Finances - Financial Overhaul  Rather than discussing the obvious, the results of bad decisions regarding how one spend's or does not save money, I would encourage a dialogue that looks at the "root cause" of financial woes, both for individuals and corporations. We also must not forget the fact that 'corporation's' are groups of 'individuals'!¬†  There is a money management system in place, and has been since the beginning of time, that if followed correctly benefits everyone. ¬†It's simply: "1 + 1 = 2", "2 - 1 = 1", "0 + 0 = 0". Problem is this simple money management system does not work when emotionalism takes a front seat.  All human beings need to feel secure within themselves. How that security looks to each one is different as habits are formed early on in a person's life; before grade school! If a person has learned to make decisions using emotions as their 'yardstick', the outcome's can be disastrous. ¬†  Some of the causes of emotional spending are triggered by fear; the fear of being lonely, being unloved, not being able to live as one has become accustomed, no longer able to satisfy selfish desires, no longer accepted by those who are privileged. Fear turn's simple task's into monstrous nightmare's.  My opinion is that most of our governing laws have been created and put into action based on "individual's" emotion's. You must have an emotional experience that moves you to action. Something must be triggered deep within your soul which prompts you to 'do something'. When making critical decisions regarding finances, ask yourself this question, "How will this decision affect me as well as those around me"? [affect - "produce a change"¬† effect - "result" / ability to bring about a result. ] ¬†If at any point and time you find yourself unable to stop and ask this question before you act, then there's a good possiblity the outcome will not be the most desirable.  I also believe there is always hope! Just because your circumstances seem bleak to impossible right now, remember a journey begins with the first step. Stop where you are and begin anew. Look back only to understand those things that got you where you are today; and be honest. Start a new journey by doing things differently. Also always keep alert as life is a constant change; each new day brings about newness.¬†  Matthew 5:37King James Version (KJV)  37 But let your communication be, Yea, yea; Nay, nay: for whatsoever is more than these cometh of evil.  5:1‚Äì7:29 The Sermon on the Mount is the first of five great blocks of Jesus‚Äô teaching in Matthew (Introduction: Characteristics and Themes). It is the classic statement of the ethics of the kingdom of God. The early church favored a literal interpretation but fully applied the sermon only to special classes of Christians, especially monastics. Others, such as the Anabaptists, have attempted to apply it literally to every Christian. Still others have viewed it as legalistic, as a provisional, temporary code, or as a heightening of the law of Moses with the aim of inducing repentance (Luther). Finally, some have argued that the demands of the sermon are not to be understood literally, but that Jesus was concerned with inward disposition rather than outward conduct, or that the severity of the sermon is intended to compel a decision by the hearers either for or against God‚Äôs demands on their lives.  We must recognize that the sermon is directed to the disciples and through them to the whole church today. The sermon addresses both inward motives and outward conduct (5:21, 22, 27, 28). These legitimate demands are so strict (5:48) that no one can completely obey them, and we are therefore driven to the grace and mercy of God. In some cases Jesus uses obviously intentional exaggeration to illustrate the absolute requirements of God‚Äôs law (5:29, 30). (01:21) "...because of a financial system that leaves millions underserved." Partially true, and here's the truth of the statement: ¬†The Federal Government has made cheap money available to banks, and banks still maintain very high interest rates on credit cards. ¬†All consumers must service loans having interest rates that are substantially higher than what banks pay for the money that they are given by the Federal Reserve. ¬†Considering the rates charged to banks, home loans should be hovering at about 2 percent, student loans should be at about 3 percent, and credit card interest rates should be at about 10 percent.  There is another side to this story. ¬†Manufacturing has slipped from America and has been sent to China, India, Bangladesh, and Vietnam. ¬†Americans must compete with extremely desperate people for work that used to pay a living wage. ¬†Some argue that if only Americans would get rid of that pesky minimum wage, and those ridiculous clean air and water regulations, everything would be great! ¬†If "great" means being paid less per hour than the cost of a small potato, then I guess things would be great, but I don't think that's a "great" idea.  I do not understand why Americans (even the desparate) are so against re-establishing tariffs on imported manufactured goods. ¬†What is so wrong with that? ¬†What is so wrong with employing Americans, FIRST? ¬†Clearly, giving our manufacturing away to the rest of the world has not made it a more stable place. ¬†Look at how China is rattling its sword at Japan and Taiwan. ¬†Look at what's going on in the Ukraine. ¬†Look at the continuing horrors going on in the Middle East!  Giving away American wealth has not made the world safer, and it has destroyed America's financial foundation.

I gotta say this documentary was not a very good advocate for the poor. ¬†They did a good job of showing the initial emergency that started the downward spiral. ¬†But, mostly....these people just seemed foolish and lacked the ability to do very basic math. ¬†Is our high school education really this bad? ¬†If so....that's another problem that needs to be looked at. ¬†I feel for these people and agree they deserve better treatment, nonetheless, they certainly were digging their own holes. ¬† I can recommend two mind blowing documentaries about what's really going on that will actually educate people who already have a good grasp of economics and art majors alike. ¬†"Inequality For All" and "Death By China". ¬†They are both on Netflix and I can't stress how important these two documentaries are. ¬†There is class warfare going on....and it's not being waged by the poor. ¬†

I have several thoughts after watching this.  1.¬†I agree that the banking and credit systems are rigged against poor people. Practical regulation seems reasonable, but most Republicans and many/most Democrats are against common sense anything.  2. Many of these folks made basic, bad¬†financial decisions. The gal trying to build her hand bag business should have 1) Chosen a cheaper college, 2) Worked during college, 3) Gotten a job in her industry right out of college, and 4) Built her own business on the side. She did do something practical: not have kids before she could afford them.  3. Which brings up lesson #3: Don't have kids unless you can afford them. Being¬†practical/choosy about sexual partners is best for several reasons. If you want to be promiscuous, WRAP IT UP and/or INSIST THAT YOUR PARTNER WRAP IT UP. It's not rocket science, folks.  5. Don't quiet your job to care for a relative or for any other reason unless you're FORCED to. You HAVE to take care of yourself first before you can care for others. This is NOT selfish. It's PRACTICAL.  4. The young couple trying to buy a house should not UNLESS it saves them $. If it does then she should get a 2nd job and work her a-- off to be able to afford a house on her own, then buy one with him. If it doesn't save them $, they should rent the cheapest place they can, maybe live with roommates, get a 2nd job and save up a huge down payment which will make getting a mortgage easier, even if they have to add his bad credit to hers.  5. I guess the couple whose son¬†has down's syndrome has such high medical expenses that they can't get by. One of them should get a 2nd job. I know it's tough, believe me. And of course the recent ACA health care is barely enough reform. Dumb ass conservatives and red states are against even those weak provisions on the HUGELY PROFITABLE insurance industry. Boggles the mind. Still, don't have kids unless you can afford them. Be PRACTICAL. Get health insurance at all costs. If you have to, get a 2nd job.  I've made PLENTY of poor financial decisions. BUT, my girlfriend and I haven't had kids, live in a dumpy place, never go out, watch an old, old tv (dvd only), don't have cable, drive old cars, buy cheap food, rarely buy clothing unless we really need it, and rarely buy fun things (music, movies, camping gear, etc.). We MAKE things last. We don't care if we look poor. WE ARE.  I know these folks are doing the best they can given their past decisions. And¬†I realize I'm¬†sounding judgemental here. But my point is¬†we¬†can learn from their mistakes while promoting change in the financial system AT THE SAME TIME. They're not mutually exclusive.  I'm certainly PISSED about the rich continually getting richer while we poor folk wallow in never-ending poverty. I'm also just about¬†given up hope on our politicians to do¬†much good for us.¬†The one thing we, the common people, CAN do is be PRACTICAL.  I just want to encourage all people, especially young people, to:  1. Spend LESS than you earn. 2. Make do with old things. 3. Don't have kids unless you can afford them. If that means you never have kids, oh well. At least you have security. 4. Work you a-- off. Get a 2nd job. 5. Choose college majors, romantic partners, spending priorities wisely. Be PRACTICAL. 6. VOTE. Lobby your state and federal senators and representatives for¬†financial and health care system reform, if you can. I know it seems helpless, but it's all we have.  TLDR: Even though the financial system sucks and needs reform, please be practical. Your future happiness depends on it.

Everything seems so unreasonably hard in the US. I live in Denmark and I use one card to withdraw money and shop - it's a debit card, but I can still buy stuff even if my account doesn't have any money (it just becomes negative) and in return I pay 18% interest a year for the overdraft. It usually amounts to a few dollars a year for me - maybe around $5 at most. We are also required by law to have a bank account and it's illegal to use individual credit ratings, so no denial of loans due to poor credit - only poor payment history or too low income. Bills go through a national standardized system, and if the bill says payment is due the 1st of July, then you can pay it the 1st of July. The company is the one that has to wait for it to clear if it doesn't clear immediately (which it most often does).

One problem I have with these sorts of documentaries is that it's all about how the big bad capitalist system is screwing people. There isn't enough attention payed to the people them selves and any poor financial decisions they made. The fact is, many Americans do stupid things with their money. I wonder how many people who "need" a payday loan only need it because they spent money on something they didn't need. You need to take care of needs FIRST, then take care of wants. You need to evaluate a "need" to see if it's really a need. Far to many people spend money on "needs" that aren't really needs. Then they don't have enough money to pay their power bill or whatever. Also, when people have more money; rather than saving it, they spend it! I remember when my dad got a better paying job. He decided to upgrade to digital cable. The basic cable we had was just fine. We had plenty of channels to choose from. But he decided to go for the more expensive option because he could. It would have been better to take the extra money and put it in savings. This sort of thing happens all the time. People get a raise and suddenly they need a new car, or TV, or whatever. People need to stop trying to keep up with the Joneses.  I am an Anarchist so I am opposed to Capitalism. It would be great if we could abolish such a horrible and exploitive economic system and replace it with something more just. But that's not going to happen any time soon. So as long as we have the kind of system we do, we need to educate people so they can make better financial decisions. That is an uphill batter unfortunately. People who are smart with money aren't as profitable as people who are dumb with money. All those fees and interest add up to a whole lot of profit.

Purple, you're right. I live in a poor neighborhood and I see it everyday. People get their checks cashed at small fee shops nearby and they are cash rich for a few days, then they're asking to borrow money by the 15th of the month, 2 full weeks before their next check. I feel for these people but here are a few tips for the poor: - Don't have kids. Period. Not one.¬† - Sell your car (bus passes are cheap), or trade it in for a smaller vehicle that would be better on gas, cheaper insurance, cheaper registration fees etc. - Scale down to a smaller home or apartment, even in a worse part of town. - Get a damn bank account. - Cut out all unnecessary expenditures. How do you afford a $150/mo phone bill if you're truly poor? - Stop buying expensive processed foods. The nurse in this documentary needs to focus more on keeping herself healthy. If an obese person is applying for a physically demanding job like a nurse, of course they won't get it.¬† If anything there should be more financial literacy education in America, especially among high risk areas. Ultimately I'd like to see society take care of each other better so parents that have special needs kids or people with elderly parents won't have to scrape like this. However, people in a free society are ultimately responsible for their own positions.¬† I moved to Hawaii when I was 19 with NOTHING. I hustled to get a shit job at a Korean BBQ joint working the grill, took a room in a house in a terrible neighborhood and bought a bus pass. I did all my shopping in China town for cheap produce and meat, learned to cook rice and other cheap staples and only shopped at second hand clothing shops. Every day I had off, I hustled for a better job, and I found one in a few months. I saved all my money and got a nice apartment in a better neighborhood with a few roommates and slowly increased my standard of living. I didn't get help from anyone because I didn't expect it. Keep in mind this was in 2007, the start of a terrible recession, so it wasn't easy. I'm not saying everyone has the same circumstances as me, some are much worse, but these people need to see that their decisions are leading them to the financial pain they are in.¬†

Brian Dupre I hadn't thought about the phone bill. I wonder how many poor people are running around with expensive smart phones? I understand the value in having a cell phone; but if you are really poor, get a cheap prepay phone. Ditching the car is also a good idea. Between public transit and a bicycle, you can do quite a bit. I do of course understand that some areas are better for public transit and bikes than others. Yes ditching processed food is the way to go. The processed crap may seem cheap, but it's not compared to real food purchased in bulk. I can get rice for $20-$22 for a 40 pound bag. Or half that for a 20 pound bag. I just recently picked up 20 pound bags of pinto beans for $15. Rice and Beans make cheap staples in ones diet. Potatoes are also a cheap option and have vitamin C. You just need to make sure to eat the skin since that's where most of the vitamins are. I used to be on food stamps. I would find my self running out of food stamps and having to visit the food bank a the end of the month. The only reason I ran out, is because I was buying processed junk. I had been buying food that only has one ingredient in it, I would have had more than enough with food stamps.

purplemutantas¬†You have the right ideas. I was raised by my grandparents for a few years (who were raised in the depression) and they taught me at 15 years old more than anyone has since about simple ways to make money. They line-dried their clothes most of the year, bought off-brand staples and grew as much produce as possible in the summer, saving those potatoes and winter squash for the fall and winter. They split a car, had a house with ONE bathroom (oh my! The horror!) and took quick showers. They opened windows on cool days and turned off the ac, they opened blinds on warm days and turned down the heat. I think we've all been sold on this disposable, semi-luxury lifestyle where we think it's weird to eat zuchini from a garden, but perfectly normal to drop $15 on lunch when we make $10/hr, but we can't blame the system, you have to realize if you're not rich that's ok, but maybe you shouldn't have a 50" tv and go spending like you have money in the bank. One way my wife and I save money when we can't garden is shopping at ethnic grocery stores because they always have cheap produce and like you said, beans are cheap as fuck, put a little hot sauce on them and they're great! We bought a $50k house in the hood and got a BIG dog and for the most part it's been ok. Some of my friend's are weird about coming to my neighborhood but I'm not going to spend $1,200/mo on an apartment I will never own to impress people who already like me. Think outside the box people, there is opportunity EVERYWHERE!

So easy to say isn't it? Regardless of how people end up in the dire positions they find themselves in, there are people who are genuinely responsible in trying to get themselves out of it...and the issue here is that the system is designed in such a way that it keeps people in that rut for as long as possible, no matter how genuine their efforts may be. It's thought processes like yours (I.e., assuming that anyone who's poor only has themselves to blame) that keeps policy makers from making any effort to do anything to help the overall. Yes, life is life and no one owes anyone any favors - especially from a business to an individual...but when I say "help," I don't mean handouts..I mean for instance making illegal the dishonest practice of banks purposely rearranging the order in which transactions are processed for the sole purpose of maximizing overdraft fees - if I have enough money to cover transactions 1 through 4 but not for number 5, you claiming I didn't have enough money for any of them is a flat out abusive lie.  Only people who've struggled to make ends meet for an extended period of time know how expensive it is to be poor, and how much of a perpetual downward spiral it can be once you even step a toe into it. Believe me, I've been on both sides of the coin before and when you have money, it's so easy to judge others who don't. Luckily I'm back on the horse but to imply that it's easy to make one's way back is ignorant; money gives you options in life.

Christian J Harris I am not simply blaming people for being poor. I know the system is stacked against poor people. I am against Capitalism, or did you not see the part where I mentioned that I am an Anarchist? My point was that there isn't enough emphasis placed on peoples poor choices. Many people do stupid things with money. I am poor and I have made poor choices with money in the past. I have some money coming in soon. I am not going to be stupid with that money. Since the system is sacked against me (poor and Autistic), I need to be as smart as I can with what little money I have. I am not going to end up getting a loan if I can help it.

Agreed about the overdraft fees, Christian. However, remember that there are thousands of banks and local credit unions, many of which don't use many of these tactics, especially the CU's. Again there are two big issues with the poor, education and access. If the families in this documentary who run around paying bills at separate locations put some effort into starting a small account at a credit union, they could avoid many of those fee's and ruthless practices. The main thing is getting educated about HOW these banks are fucking you, and get access to a better system like a CU, and don't tell me it might not be convenient for them, because they clearly aren't afraid to drive an hour round trip for bills. There is an incredible amount of coddling and apathy among the poor. Yes yes yes there are certain extenuating circumstances and a lot of people are destitute, but if they truly are, they can frequently get government assistance. They need the education to learn what programs they can take advantage of, and access to those programs. Education and access. This is where programs like the United Way come in.¬† You're correct, it IS a rut, and a downward spiral but you have to get in the right mindset too. In this documentary, the nurse is on the phone with her boss/coordinator. She hasn't worked in over a year and is having a hard time getting her foot in the door. The person on the phone offers her a job (temp, daily, weekly whatever) and instead of saying, "Yes! Yes! I'll take it, thanks you for the opportunity!" She hesitates and says, "Oh, that's an hour away....". That is a losing attitude. She could have sucked it up, gone for that hour drive and knocked her potential new boss's socks off with great service, but she hesitated.¬† It doesn't matter if you have a master's degree, no one owes you a thing. For instance, we don't know particulars but the nurse didn't have to take care of her mother. If her mother was truly destitute, that is what medicaid and medicare and social security is for. If she had stayed at her (assuming since she has such a high education level) high paying nursing job and hired a home caretaker to come watch her mother for a few hours during the days she worked, it sounds like she wouldn't be in this situation. That being said, many people with college degrees know little to nothing of personal finance and common sense. Her apartment looks awful nice for someone who is "poor" and her daughter goes to private school. There is a ton of waste in that woman's finances and I know she thinks this is the correct way to do things, and her and her family deserve it, but that doesn't make it reality.¬† As a society, we need to realize this is a new normal. We are taught that our standard of life will never decline, that housing is a concrete investment, that a college degree will always pay for itself and that we deserve cheap, plentiful goods. This is incorrect. They call it the American Dream because you'd have to be asleep to believe it.¬† Also, if you are interested in this system and why it can't really work, check out Jacque Fresco, Peter Joseph or various Anarcho-Capitalists, you might learn a lot and awaken a spirit of resistance to the current system we have. We all deserve housing, food, community and love, but that isn't the current system and until we change it, you need to be flexible and adapt to the current system, not hold on to your current lifestyle with a death grip. Suck up your pride; downsize your living quarters, get rid of your car, get rid of your expensive phone, start shopping at thrift shops, grow your own food, find temporary work, stop buying people gifts for made-up-corporate holidays (Christmas). Think outside the box, because it clearly isn't working for you!

S Dutchguy No people don't choose to have cancer or Autism. But people DO choose to have children. People also choose where they spend their money when times are good. If you are going to have a child you should be prepared for the reality that the child might be born with a disability. People should also be prepared for disasters, whatever they may be. Besides typical things like food, water, and other disaster supplies; people should also have money saved up. I think most people in the US can afford to save some money. I bet most people aren't spending 100% of their money on real actual needs. Even if all you can afford to save is $5 a month, it adds up. I have some money coming in and plan on setting most of it aside for emergencies.

Chavez Lives¬†That is not an example of a poor decision. If your friend spent his money in the past on cars and houses, the purchases would have depreciated, broken, etc. and eventually lost value or even been stolen, etc. Occasionally, possessions can increase in value, but usually they are a liability in regards to needing to pay to secure them, maintain them, pay yearly taxes or fees, or insure them. The doctor would have eventually run out of money just to maintain his "stuff". He saved, but as you mentioned, inflation does eat up savings. But, it has not always been this way. Savings rates are very low due to lending rates being low. (no new businesses and less people buying homes, etc. )So, saving money is not the way to get ahead in a down economy, although it can create a bit of comfort and security to the saver. Yet, spending money only brings a temporary satisfaction and is risky and ends up being like the video: a never ending cycle of paying debt, paying for repairs, robbing "peter to pay paul", etc. What is the worst in today's economic climate is that people are spending money, but it is not so much on actual goods or things that we like or enjoy, but rather fees and invisible things. This certainly is less enjoyable than reflecting back on purchases that at least gave a spender a bit of pleasure. It's like being forced to pay for repairs or continually fix a car that no longer takes you anywhere but circles...

Markus Hallcyon¬†Paragraph or sentence? ¬†In 2009, I had to look up all the isms. ¬†Marxism, capitalism, , fascism, socialism, communism, terrorism, etc. ¬†I wanted to see what the U.S. was currently practicing. ¬†Turns out, we're a mutt. ¬†The U.S. is practicing all the isms except communism because apparently that form of governance is just a fantasy. ¬†The main reason that we don't have capitalism is because the U.S. doesn't have money, we have currency in the form of the fiat dollar but no real money. ¬†Currency lacks the essential store of value necessary for it to be considered money. ¬†Because we don't have money, we really don't know what the true price of goods and services should be. ¬†An example of crony capitalism, what should be real price of food be? ¬†The government pays certain farmers not to grow food, it also subsidizes farmers who grow certain crops like corn, wheat and soy. ¬†Govt prevents the sale of produce that doesn't look a certain way such as cucumbers have to be straight so that they are stackable in the shelves and not curved, ridiculous. ¬†Govt protects large food corporations with tax breaks and punitive regulations. ¬†The FDA lets certain ingredients like sugar, HFCS, MSG and other toxic additives to be hidden in the ingredient lists under different names. ¬†MSG alone can be hidden in the ingredient list under 53 different names. ¬†The USDA Organic label is enormously expensive to get and helps to raise the price of organic food produce and products. ¬†And if a food is really good for helping with preventing or helping cure a disease or symptom the food company cannot promote it's advantages to human health, for example, Tart Cherry Juice actually works better than aspirin for pain, yet millions of gallons of tart cherry juice is thrown away because it cannot get sold. ¬†This is not capitalism, the U.S. is just pretending that we have capitalism. ¬†We still have a little bit of capitalism which is why the U.S. economy hasn't completely collapsed, but we're getting to that point.¬†

I am 57 years old. Lived through recessions, depressions & on & on. In the early 80's, my husband & I both lost our jobs. We had just bought a house & had two children. We endured calls from collection agencies constantly. We ate the government cheese. While others were bankrupting, we trudged ahead feeling it was our moral obligation to pay our debts. If I had it to do over again, I would RUN (not walk) to bankruptcy court. Our bad credit followed us around for years. Those who had their debts dissolved in court were back on their feet years before we were. Then, if I couldn't pay the mortgage, the bank could take the house back. I would go to social services & get section 8 housing, food stamps & a medicaid card. We are still struggling in spite of being hard working people. In the end we'll be no better off than those who never hit a lick of work a day in their lives. We'll be in the same government run nursing homes. Hide & watch. If I sound bitter, perhaps it's because I am. Just a little.

29:00 She has more orders than she can deal with, that's awesome! She says her challenge is that she doesn't have enough money to buy the materials.  Steve jobs had this exact same problem when he started Apple. He got an order of I believe 50 Macintoshes, but didn't have the money. So he negotiated with the supplier and with the buyer.  If she offers the buyer bettter terms for upfront payment, or for paying half upfront (or whatever the cost of materials is), she can buy the materials and still make the products and build her critical mass financially.  Or she can do the same with the supplier, negotiate, explain the situation, if necessary offer to pay slightly more for credit terms.  While I don't know her situation, there are solutions which people can find on an individual level. Sure systematic change is necessary long term, and we're working towards that. It's just that that isn't the only valid paradigm of solutions.

I tend to agree with you.¬† Via trial and error I have found out how to work the personal financial system.¬† The secret is not avoid debt, but to manage it better.  The way I handle this situation is a little complex but it is definately less work & cost than running around with cash everywhere and pay day loans.¬† I get all my bills paid in about 2 hours.  Get yourself 2 checking accounts with¬†little or no fees¬†and¬†3 to 5¬†credit cards with no annual fees.  One of your checking accounts is your receiving account / main account.¬† It is the account that your pay checks, etc. go to.¬† You use this account to pay your debts.¬† NEVER, EVER have any auto-debits on this account.¬†¬†  The other checking account is for the "auto debit" items you run into.¬† You keep this seperate from your main account because auto debits will screw you up so easy.¬† Try to have about twice the amount of monthly auto debits in this account.¬† That way if forget to move money over or run into problems, you can afford to miss the month.¬† I always pay about $10 to $50 more than I need to break even on this account.¬† It is amazing how quickly that extra $30 a month builds up.  Now one of your credit cards is your "all expenses card".¬† This card is usually the card that has points or cash back.¬† You pay for pretty much everything with this card.¬† At the end of the month you review your spending when you pay your bills.¬† If you spend about your budget or less, GREAT!¬† You pay off the full balance of your credit card, paying no interest and earning some points in the process.¬† Take the extra cash and save it or use it pay down another credit card.¬†¬†¬†If you spend more than your budgeted, you look and see where you are wasting your money.¬† You make mental notes that you are wasting too much money.¬† And you try to make it up next month.¬† Never over draft your "main account", just pay less on your "all expenses card".¬† The interest on your "all expenses card" will be much less than the overdraft fee.  The other credit cards are "competition" cards.¬† The reason I call them this is because credit cards are aware of your other cards, and want your business.¬† And they are willing to offer you all kinds of deals to get you to use them.¬† They will compete for you.¬†If one of your credit cards is giving your problems or you run into a major financial problem, you do not pay your "all expenses card" from your "main checking account".¬† Instead that month you pay the "all expenses card"¬† with a balance transfer from a "competition card", and use the money that built up in your¬† main account from your pay checks.¬† Using this method you pay little to no fees, and the interest rates on balance transfers is very low (typically 0% to 6% annually).¬† You then work out how to pay down that "competition card".  Here is¬†the best advice I can give anyone.¬† Take every no annual fee credit card you can get.¬† ESPECIALLY WHEN YOU DON'T NEED IT.¬† Take it, then throw the card in a drawer and never use it or carry it with you.¬† Some day that little bit of liquidity could be a life saver.¬† That is because when your finances are¬†mediocre to bad¬†no one will want to give you a credit card.¬†

I see lots of well-fed, healthy people talking about how much it costs to go to the movies, roller-blading,¬†living in single-family homes, working their own businesses, and discussing how the money they get must be used to care for their needs. Um, yea. They are clean, warm, hair is done. They own electronics - tvs, cell phones, video cameras, microphones, stoves. They haveeye glasses,¬†a closet of clothes, drive cars, and have been fully educated. Their kids have toys and time to play instead of working or scrounging for food. They are wearing jewlery, playing guitars, and sleeping in beds. I see lots of doo-dads in their houses that could have been savings instead.¬†I know it's not easy, but compared to 90% of the world's population - this is high-living rich to where they can't even fathom living with as much excess. I think we have become so focused on ourselves and what we don't have that we neglect to really see and appreciate how much we do have. I've seen lots of comments aboutthe rich getting richer and the poor getting poorer. those that know what to do with money, how to get it, save it, invest it, will aqcuire more. Those that do not know, will repel money. It boils down to education and changing how we think and what we do first, then all those things will be added to us. I may not be "there" yet, but I am grateful and can see how much I really have, and am learning to do better each day by self-education in finance and money. The banking and money system is working - for themselves - making profit. It does not work for those¬†that do not know money handling.¬†Check cashing places are the same as banks - making profit. Our grandparents and generations before lived on cash and only bought what they could save and pay for. This is not a hardship - this is the way to handle money.¬†Financial Peace University with Dave Ramsey (highly recommended), Rich Dad Poor Dad with Robert Kiyosaki, The Millionaire Next Door book by Thomas J. Stanley and a host of other books, classes, seminars - I educate myself every day to counter what I grew up learning, and to do better every day.

No argument from me that the financial system is gouging these people but they are in a large part doing it to themselves and supporting this system that is raping them.  Basically, all these people know they are spending money on fees because they don't have a bank account. ¬† now the film doesn't really go into why people don't just open a bank account. ¬†these people seem to have jobs and make some money. ¬†open a bank account and deposit your money into there like most people. ¬†is that really that hard? ¬†  spend less than you make to avoid overdraft fees. ¬†the people in this documentary seem to have nice places to live and pretty nice cars... ¬†maybe they need to tone down their standard of living and save. ¬†when I was growing up, my entire family had one car. ¬†a chevy malibu that we bought used and was 5 shades of blue and rust. ¬†it had no AC and the seats were ripped but it got us around. ¬†we minimized driving it to save on gas and planned our shopping and errands to the most efficient routes and did them together. ¬†i never had any new clothing until college. ¬†never went to a movie theater. ¬†i think we went out to eat at someplace akin to soup plantation once a year. ¬†the first time i went to a fast food joint was my senior year of high school. ¬†our entire family lived in two bedrooms in a house we rented with 2 other families. ¬†we had no furniture and slept on the floor and ate at a small folding table on the floor. ¬†didn't have a TV, never ran the AC in the house, barely ran the heat enough to make sure it wasn't too cold, took navy showers, cut our own hair. ¬†my parents immigrated to the US with two small boys and worked insanely hard and we lived on less than 1000 a month but somehow they managed to put us through school and even save a little bit to take care of the unexpected emergencies. ¬†they opened a bank account and always spent less than they made no matter how little they made.  every single one of the people in this documentary make more money and live MUCH more luxuriously than my family did when I was a child. ¬†but they are making the choices that keep themselves there. ¬†know my brother and I are adults and my parents live in a house that they own and they are retired and have saved enough to be comfortable in their retirement and even get to travel and enjoy a retirement they richly deserve. ¬† my brother and I both have good jobs and are while we don't live extravagantly, we are both comfortably in the upper middle class and don't have any real financial concerns. ¬† our present situation would not be possible had my parents not made the sacrifices they did when we were younger. ¬† more personal responsibility and good choices is what people need more than anything.

I'm going to go out on limb here but the entire point of the video is that people who screw up are punished with poverty and people who as some put it "were unwilling" to be born in the middle class or higher find it hard to make ends meet with nobody to support them or stop them from making bad decisions. These are not some sort of majority as some would like to put it but examples of when this financial system doesn't work. (which in my opinion is often enough to want change in the financial system). Nono but now you are going to complain that I 'don't get the bigger picture'. This is the bigger picture. Use your heads now everyone. Really think about this. Does the financial system in the world function as it should in a¬†hypothetical perfect¬†society? Not 'does it work'. Is it a functional potential system I would want for my children to raise their children under?¬†No. But again this is not good enough for you I bet so I will elaborate. This system works, yes but why? It is because a select group of people have power and they¬†use that power to maintain order using money. Now everything seems all fine and dandy on the surface but I guarantee many fall through the cracks (nope caught you before you tried it this is not an exclusively American thing it is a bigger issue regarding the world's economy which is based entirely on money and power...which is also money.) Think of America, my country, as an oil baron of the world. If you restructure laws then he will just pay the congress off to look the other way or he will make a loophole. How do you keep the baron from holding all the seats in congress? Devalue money. Money is the bigger issue but not in the 'root of all evil' kind of way. Why do people fall through the cracks? Because you can't get money without someone else losing money (an old law that was supposed to spare us this problem but the barons found a way) First step- war. Make the government spend all its money to raise taxes for some war in Afghanistan or better yet Iraq maybe the oil barons might get some profit. Taxes raised on the poor, evade taxes by shipping their money overseas. Step two- lock the middle class behind the poverty line. This could take longer but soon enough they will be 'tough enough' to only need the minimum amount of money to live so we can lower the wages so we can keep the rest. Step three(important)- use news channels and the government to make everyone think everything is okay. Wait I hear a voice in the distance trying to disprove everything I have stated by brushing it off as paranoia. Nope you don't get that loophole either. It has long been known that lobbyists exist and that congress doesn't vote the way of the people (democracy my ass if they ignore the people) and that the media (especially fox) is a bunch of stacked cards. But, oh, I hear you trying another argument that I am circling the problem well if you insist I will hit the hammer on the head. This financial system doesn't work. The world's financial system doesn't work. Let's pretend for a moment it was a good idea like most of you think. It's not going the way it is supposed to. Person A runs numbers and gets ahead, person B works hard and has no time to count numbers. Person A is now richer than person B because he is working on legal loopholes. Is it right to reward this kind of behavior? Should you win monopoly by a loophole in the rulebook? That should be considered 'weak and soft'. I hate my job and I know that I'm too good for it but I can't run off and write a book because I can't support myself. Is that right? Am I allowed use my fucking degree in English to earn a dime? Not in this country. Not in this world. I can only write on the side. If I'm not too busy working both my jobs or getting medical issues I can't afford to treat. Sorry I'm too 'soft' for some of you. Ok that's enough pretending, Earth. This system doesn't work. It's based off a gold standard back when apparently all people cared about was gold. Why change it? It still applies because now, all people care about is money. But nothing's going to change. Many at least got that right I suppose. Nothing will change because we are too lazy and we don't want it to change.¬†It's just like the education system (which I could also tear down because its crap) we will spend billions and billions trying to fix it instead of the effort of making one that works. Why? I'll tell you why. We don't want to think anything is wrong. That's why we believe the media anyway. That's why every man that knows in his heart somewhere everything's been screwed up somehow but won't say a word on his way to his job, the bar, home. "Everything's going to be okay' we keep saying 'We survived this long. Others have made it,¬†I can make it'. Take it from a fellow philosopher life shouldn't be about struggle but we are going about this wrong. We struggle against change instead of struggling to stop struggle. People struggle to live but we look the other way. All we can think is 'I'm glad I'm not him' you know what the beggars think? They're not thinking 'I deserve this. This is justice. I will suffer till I die for what I have done' I'm looking at a bigger issue we see every day and just walk by without a thought sometimes. Society. It needs to change. We need a country just one little place where they try something new this time. A place where it doesn't have to be the same thing every day if you don't like it that way. We need to move on. The time for screwing around with resources and money when we damn well know that when we die, all we will care about are the smiles and the friends and the love and the moments. I'm not saying leave the world to burn becuase I'm going to die anyway, I'm saying most of these 'problems' these nations are facing are issues we already have solutions for. Like the 'energy crisis'. More like 'organize so we can save our planet!, oh well we tried back to natural gas I guess'. But if nothing in my life changes the only thought in my head will be 'Guess I won't write a book' when I die. That's not right. That's inhumane. I care more for people and inspiration than I ever did for money and look where I am. What justice is this? We need to move on but all our leaders have to say is 'There's just too many people with too many opinions, we can't change all their minds. Our way has worked for a millennia. If we disarm our nukes Russia will kill us all I know it.' And when I tell them what I think they say 'We are not ready maybe in a century, or ten, we need to figure ourselves out first'. They are right. The world isn't willing to change just yet. But every day I know I won't see the world I dream of. It only seems more and more distant. I wonder If the world will ever change. Or if we will just keep saying 'Just one more century of tradition and being on top' 'one more' 'one more' until all of existence is gone. We are not ready to take our lives, the world, or the issues of finances seriously. So long as we can go on our merry way and our kids can pay for another tombstone why not? One more¬†century then... then we will change. So nothing's going to change now but... the least we can do is throw people a damn bone. Especially if they have a dream. That is what this video is about. There's nothing to argue about. There's nothing to disagree with. It's just what we all want. But God only knows if the people who actually make decisions in this country will do something, anything to help people other than themselves. You don't have to agree with everything I said. My point stands. I really can't imagine anybody arguing against what is morally right and wrong. I'll understand if you want to argue for money. I'll understand if you want to fight about grammar. Just remember that we agree that at least one thing is not as right as it should be, society. And thanks for reading.

When I got my University degree twenty years ago, it cost me $180 in the first year in fees. That was when they first started charging fees for University. The next year was $1200 and the next year was $1800. Now the kids pay about $30 000 for a degree. My how things change. My degree was in Social Science. I think Americans might describe that as the Liberal Arts. Back in those days almost every college graduate (in NZ) would go on to a University Degree majoring in something. That was just what everyone did. After I got my degree, I decided to become a chef and went to trade college. After working as a chef for fifteen years I became a trainer and educator in the culinary arts and a coordinator within the Catholic Social Services. If I had to do a degree today, I would choose that to be in finance and economics. I would probably not be of much use to the community in general but I would be able to pay back my loans, make money for the finance industry and have plenty left over for myself. I am glad that I can make a contribution to the community in some way by my good luck. I would rather that than having to chase the almighty dollar just to survive.¬†

I get that the American economy (especially financial institutions) do not adequately serve the majority of the population. But I find it hard to feel sorry for the people that are profiled. The leather maker did not need to spend a hundred large in school to make purses. The nurse chose to quit her job to care for her mother. Presumably, the musician did not purchase a disability policy that would have replaced his income in the event of illness. The video service kid really needs to get his act together before settling down.¬† All choices and consequences. Having an autistic boy is a curve ball that nobody wants to hit.¬† But everyone who has kids risks that they will have severe problems.  The documentary spends a lot of time bemoaning the payday companies, etc. I too think that these predatory lenders are loathsome dirt bags who have no qualms about rifling through peoples' pockets for loose change as they nail the coffin shut.¬† But there always has been and always will be people to enrich themselves through the misfortune of others. It seems that the implication here is that we need to change our financial systems and I agree. It is good that the video points out new and creative forms of financing for those not served by existing banks.  But I find it troubling that those profiled are portrayed as victims. Most of us will suffer great misfortune during our lives. Americans have gotten too soft and too weak. Many are now content to wait for someone else to fix their problems, wondering why they are stuck in a rut.¬† Fixing financial systems is important, but certainly less so than fixing attitudes and the willingness to change.  ¬†

It is quite an interesting, yet confusing system.  In Germany you can, in most cases, pay using cash or bank cards only. The latter means that the money is substracted DIRECTLY from your account, without fee. If you do not have money in your account, you get an error message directly from the device that reads your card (those devices are connected to your bank's central system using a live connection).  Credit cards are accepted only in a handful of stores. Some services like car rentals, hotels and a few others accept credit cards.   The most important difference is: the MORE loans and credit lines you had (or tried to get), the LESS your credit score is. If you never tried to get a loan and you have a well-paid job, your are most likely to get any credit you want.

TheVinster17¬†...How did they screw themselves up? They are all hardworking and faced extraordinary circumstances. The point of the documentary was that people in need of financial aid are often no different than you and I, and they certainly don't fit into the 'lazy moocher' stereotype perpetuated by the right.

Well....lets see.  Debbie) Took out 100k in student loans (where on earth did she go) to make handbags.  Nurse) quit her job when she should have put her mom in a home with her mom's own money. Kept her daughter in expensive private school and took out a loan on her (fairly new) car, but she forgot to read the contract.  The young couple) Dead set on buying a house for unknown reasons, but pissed off that their credit sucks because he decided he was not going to pay his loans (wth?)

Are you arguing that students should not attend prestigious (but costlier) schools that befits their academic merit? Also, student loans have interest fees that accumulate over time. I'm Canadian so I can't attest to American student loans, but I do know that in Canada, even after the government heavily subsidizes our post-secondary education, tuition and living expenses are still very expensive (over 10k a year). As for the latter part of your statement "to make handbags", I think you are acting deliberately dismissive towards small-business entrepreneurs. It's not just about 'making handbags', but about running your own business as your own chief executive. That's a business degree right there. Also, there are degrees for craftspeople and designers too, both of which she has to be in order for her business to be successful.  As for the nurse, you are talking from a position of hindsight and a position with insufficient facts (as am I). It's easy to say what she /should've/ done, but in her contingency moment, she had evaluated her education and work experience and decided that she could be easily rehired. Plus she left her job because she had savings that could support her during her leave of absence. She could not have possibly forecasted or prevented the 2008 recession. I only hope that if your significant family member got diagnosed with an incurable and life-threatening illness, you would not be so heartless as to ship them away to a retirement home so that you could instead focus on your career. Also, the reason why her daughter was in a private school in the first place was because she was doing very well as a professional nurse, before the extaordinary circumstances occurred. As for the car, she knew exactly what she had signed up for. The point was that even once she put her car up in order to get some quick cash to repay previous loans, she could not repay back this new loan fast enough as well. The point is to illustrate the broken nature of this financial system, whereby supposedly remedial measures just end up leading to even more debt.  The young couple wanted to buy the house to start a family and because his lease was ending, not for "unknown reasons". I hope you think this is a worthy reason. His credit also sucks because in his youth, he had to put himself through the education system as well as earn a living for himself. His credit sucks not because he was lazy and a moocher, but rather because, in spite of his hard work, he did not start off on an even playing field and he accumulated debt every time his meager wages could not balance his educational and living expenses.  I do have to wonder though - why are you so keen on being a victim-blaming apologist for these wealthy loan companies that capitalise on other peoples' suffering?

No one has perfect information to make the best choice at every point in their life, but this is one of the basic foundational assumption necessary for an economical analysis based on free market principles.¬† So many aspects of the banking system exist to profit off of the mistakes of others, and to opportunistically prey on people's vulnerabilities.¬† That these banks charge overdraft fees or even charge at all for their services, is laughably crooked.¬† When an individual has money in their bank account, the bank uses that money on investments that provide profit quickly enough that no one notices that their money is missing.¬† As part of the fractional reserve banking system, a bank can use the same physical dollar up to 10 times at once, essentially using money that does not exist on their Wall Street bets.¬† All this digitizing of money and money services have benefited the banks the most as it gives them more time to use other people's money.  On top of it all, they charge you for the privilege of given them your money so that they can profit off of you.¬† The market crash that caused the Great Depression was one that resulted in the banks using all that money and loosing it.¬† As a result, normal people had their bank accounts emptied through no fault of their own.¬†

" I do find it hilarious though, that you have already begun to rely on ad hominem by your second post. It is unwise to assume anything about someone you do not know, especially across the internet. But if you are not qualified to pass down judgement, then I had every right to make that ad-hom, because it would be completely accurate in describing your lack of qualifications - the qualifications that are a requisite for your argument from a position of authority/experience.¬†  By the way, here's a nice little ad-hominem of your own against me, directly quoted: "if you really believe you need a business degree to start a designer shop (or that it should cost anywhere near 100k even with interest), you are arguing from ignorance". I do find it hilarious though, that you would accuse someone else of using an ad-hominem when you yourself used one moments earlier. The reason why I didn't accuse you first of ad-homing me is because ad-hominems - in this discussion - are completely relevant if we deem ourselves worthy of passing judgement on whether these people made 'good' or 'bad' decisions.  "100k in student loans is a ridiculous amount, and you can hype up her chance at a "prestigious institution" all you want....it was still a DUMB choice. She should have known that 100k in student loans would generate a large pool of interest...because that is one of the first things most responsible people think about when they take out loans."  Perhaps she should have considered interest more, or perhaps, being the first person in her family admitted to university, she saw the opportunity and honour in attending the university, in spite of the high expenses. The fact that you believe that people should refuse life-bettering opportunities, especially education, for the single reason of a temporary financial deficit, shows how out of tune you are to the ideal of the 'land of opportunity'. Perhaps instead of blaming Debbie for choosing opportunity and education, you should address the direr and objectively worse problem of exponentially higher student loan interest rates than similar corporate bailout rates, or the fact that American post-secondary tuition costs so damn much in comparison to all other First World countries.  "The fact that you think these people are saints preyed upon by evil men in banking towers is about the most ridiculous thing"  If you had bothered to watch this documentary in its entirety, you would have found this one interesting segment whereby they explained the trend that banks are now closing in favour of quick-cashing businesses designed for the specific purpose of appealing to desperate people. The highlighted problem is not just about banks, but about intentionally profiteering off of the contingently downtrodden. If these companies acted more out of compassion and less like legalised loan sharks, then this documentary would not have needed to be made.  "they knew (or should have known) the terms and risks going in. Complaining about how unfair it is now is just pathetic."  Let me conclude by reiterating the fundamental premise of this documentary: every case presented therein had the commonality of experiencing external, extraordinary circumstances. Had these extraordinary circumstances not befallen the people in these cases, they would not have fallen into this perpetual cycle of financial indebtedness. Fundamentally, these people are just like any of us, and their problems lie not with their own laziness or underqualification, but rather with the overarching financial system as a whole.  Quod Erat Demonstrandum.

much blame is placed upon individuals instead of the system-at-large when considering systemic problems.¬†  If I may speculate for a moment about your possible perspective (correct me if I am wrong), is it that you believe when someone faults the system for systemic troubles that they personally experience, that they are essentially blaming you or "all people?"¬† Or maybe that they are blaming their bosses, the bankers, Wall Street, politicians, ad nauseum?¬†  In my speculation, I would disagree that there are specific people to blame for the systemic problems experienced by those in the video.¬† In general, although "people" are necessary components of a "system," they are not the only such necessary component.¬† Cultural practices, traditions, and the nature of our relationship to each other, all play necessary and critical roles in making a "system" happen.¬†  With systemic problems, how else would you go about solving them, if not by trying to illustrate the reality of such problems to people.¬† Our system discourages people who want to become more educated, or who want to get ahead in life by creating financial barriers to these things.¬† A system that encouraged people to better themselves, would more likely pay people to get an education, rather than bill them and inundate them with debt.¬† A system focused on the economic benefits of employment and production would have the infrastructure to train and relocate potential workers.¬†  Also, the "System" does not automatically mean "the government," and my examples of how a more efficient system would act are not automatically pleas for further state involvement (I am not a statist).¬† All this requires is collective action, which we typically and incorrectly attribute as "state action."¬†  Even within our current system, children are trained and educated, in part, by their family, without forcing said children to take out loans to pay for such services.¬† Tradesmen, as a practice, take on apprentices who are paid to work along side experienced tradesmen in order to get on-the-job training for that trade.¬†  Our System does not work, and I think we can do much much better.

Banking itself is a bit of a ripoff.¬† All that money people deposit into their savings/checking accounts is then used by the banks in order to make investments and bets on Wall Street.¬† They play a game of musical savings accounts where they return the money by the time someone needs it.¬† Delays and electronic transactions benefit these banks to a degree that can only be described as "incredulous."¬† Also, they can use the same dollar on up to 10 simultaneous transactions, due to our "fractional reserve banking" system.¬† This is what the "FDIC protection" is for.¬† The crash of the Great Depression resulted in the banks losing all this money.¬† With the FDIC, the federal government insures account holders up to $250,000, which sounds so nice of them, but in reality this is insurance for the banks to make reckless bets.¬† That paltry and measly interest rate you get on a savings account is a sort of compromise of the often 20%+ rate of return on the investments the bank makes with your money.¬† On top of it all, they then charge you for the privilege of given them your money so that they can rip you off.¬† Whenever you hear about increases in these fees, ATM fees, and more horrors of "overdraft protection," this is because the banks are not making enough money on their investments, and they are desperately looking for ways to recoup the money they are losing, before normal people notice.¬†
They prey on our ignorance. We must keep getting educated on the system so we can stop being a victim.
