This video should be called "Looking for Cents[sense]." Certainly these people are not stupid - I understand that they have rough things going on in their lives - but some of their financial decisions they've made are just silly. The guy that uses prepaid debit cards, for example - theres absolutely no reason he can't have a free checking account with even better online banking and bill paying services and a regular debit card for it and avoid all of those check cashing and transaction fees. He's throwing all of that money away for no reason. It only takes one business day(one evening) for a check to clear at a bank 95% of the time, what is this 3-5 day nonsense? The only way that would be the case is if you only deposit your checks after the cutoff time on a friday before a long holiday weekend, or if your checks are put on hold for some reason(which usually doesn't happen.)  Again, I understand money being tight, but tying up simple things like this with your banking would certainly lighten the load a little bit.

This was a good flagship for struggling Americans. Don't use major banks - but, if you do, they are required to let you choose a non-overdraft checking account. Don't use more than 2 credit cards and never use them for necessities. Only emergencies. If you need a debit card, never use one from those crooks at check cashing places. Paypal and Western Union have debit cards that don't charge monthly fees or fees per transaction (Paypal actually has a cash-back system). Never trust that you can be out of work for more than a month then immediately go back. Always have at least part time work, even if you don't need it. Never ever ever ever ever ever take out a payday or title loan. No matter how bad it is, even if you're starving, it will be worse very quickly with those shitbags. I got lucky; I took out a payday loan once. But I live in Texas, and most of those loans aren't enforceable in court because the fees are way above the statutory maximum here. Of course, they still try criminal methods to recover the money. I even had a guy pretend to be a process server come to my place and threaten me with a fake summons. I took the summons told the guy to leave and called the courthouse. They said the guy wasn't registered as a process server in Texas and there were no registered proceedings against me. Sufficed to say the next time he showed up he got a gun pointed at him.

***** You couldn't be more wrong in your points, especially the point you made about the relatability of the individuals being focused on. These people were picked out of a slew of other families and working class individuals because of their relatablilty. I work as a social worker, am single with no dependents, yet I was able to relate to each one of these case studies. I was able to do this quite easily because of a basic human emotion, empathy, as well as my own experiences of being days away from living on the street. Luckily this has never happened to me and due to the wonderful support of my parents, it probably never would have, but even still, I know the feeling of living pay cheque to pay cheque. Add a child or a sickly parent to the mix and I would have been completely screwed.  The diversity of the people used in this film was intentional and a wise decision. It would have been much less relatable if the people being focused on were homeless or working part-time at various low wage jobs. It has almost become expected that people living in situations like this will be struggling. It is not yet considered normal that educated, talented, hard working, smart, and capable people should be living so close to the edge, getting ever closer the more they spend away their savings to cover an continuously mounting amount of debt. Your comments are simply arrogant, making it seem as though you know you are right simply because you have your own business. As the narrator says at the end, these are people who believed in the promise of capitalism, that so long as they were willing to never give up, continuing to strive forward, that they will not be held back. This system, capitalism, used to operate on a simple premise. So long as you are willing to work hard for a living, you will be granted a comfortable life; and if you are willing to take the chance as an entrepreneur, you may do even better for yourself. But, if all else fails, a simple job with full time hours should provide you with a comfortable living. This is no longer true, the system has failed. It only continues to run on faulty investments and mythology.¬†

***** I didnt really see it the way you do. The thing I saw was a system setup to exploit people in a already bad position. Sure the women selling hand bags etc could have tried to get backing in other way, but the point was rather that.  Why is the system setup in such a way that it was no practical and easy way for her to get a average break. Why couldnt she just go to a bank and get a loan. Why was there "computer says nooo" type mentality. Why did they have to drive everywhere for petty stuff. Why was there no regulation to counter these excessive multiple fees businesses practices.  Because the system itself is setup to NOT help people like this. People that under normal circumstance would have had a easy time getting the help they needed. Having "sadder stories" would just not have showed that because it would then be more about the tragic people in the doc rather than the criticism towards the system.

Should check cashing stores be closed? Should banks refuse to pay people's bills for them? This "system" gives people choices and lots of freedom, perhaps too much credit. Without this "system" though the people would go hungry. People are free to abuse themselves in this system. The choices people make determine what limits they're under. The risks they take determine their liabilities. The girl with the bag making talent who got to borrow 100k for school loans engaged in risky behavior by doing so. There was no guarantee her degree would afford her great career opportunities. I, on the other hand could not get student loans, and had to work two, sometimes three, jobs to afford undergraduate school. My parents were nice enough to let me live at home until I finished my degree. When I got out the job that was waiting for me was to be a waste water chemist. I got to work with shit and became intimately familiar with which South Florida cities had the stinkiest shit. No bag making. No video editing. No playing music. No kid to send to private school. I hustled and smelled the shit every day and was grateful to have that job. My big dream? To work in the other room that wasn't filled with bottles and jars of shit. I have empathy, it's just that I've been around people whose conditions inspired more of it than these people do.

Of course you wouldn't have credit history. ¬†Credit is buying something by deferring payment. ¬†If you don't defer the payment, if you pay up front all the time, how can you have any credit history? ¬†And it's actually a reliable way to tell whether someone is capable of dealing with credit. ¬†If you never use it, you'll never know how you'll react to having a line of credit. ¬†But if there's history, if there's proof that (a) yes you're a good borrower or (b) no, you go crazy and can't pay it back, and banks better know where they stand in trusting you with money.  At least most of the time. ¬†Some people who look like solid borrowers have the floor drop out under them, and come crashing down into serious financial trouble. ¬†Other people who look like the biggest possible risks end up being the greatest missed opportunities for banks in the world because, not only is that person able to pay back the debt, but they end up so grateful for the opportunity that they become loyal customers.  The problem is, which ones are busts, which ones are sleepers, and which ones are exactly who they appear to be?
No actually, the person that has borrowed before and paid it back is much less likely statistically to default on the next loan versus the 30 year old that has never borrowed a dollar before.

Why? ¬†That person has literally zero experience with repaying money. ¬†Sure, they have experience with buying things they can afford, but not with buying things they can't. ¬†At least, at the moment. ¬†They can't point back to things and say "look, I didn't have the money to go to the hospital, but I did and I paid it off." ¬†Or car, house, credit card, whatever. ¬†All that person has is a history of buying what they can afford, and putting off what they can't (at that moment.) ¬†That's not reliable...it's unknown. ¬†And in the finance world, unknown is worse than bad. ¬†At least with bad credit, banks know where they stand.

NothingIsKnown¬† I have no doubt it's a better system overall to consider every aspect of a person's financial situation, not just past credit history. ¬†But at the same time, you either have to trust what the person is saying about their income, or you have to have the ability to track it. ¬†A person with a stable income might spend all of it on bills, or frivolous purchases, putting themselves in a terrible position to try and repay a loan.  If you're willing to trust them at their word, then you open yourself up to fraud and bigger risks. ¬†Eventually, if you keep getting burned, you'll stop trusting people...sort of like what happened with the housing crisis. ¬†Anyone who bought a house after the bubble burst (like me) is probably still finding magnifying glasses up their butt.  If you're not willing to trust them at their word, you have to track all of that (or at least be able to get that info). ¬†You couldn't just look at a pay stub...you'd have to have official bank records, which would just about make getting a bank account mandatory in order to get credit. ¬†(There may be other ways, but this seems the easiest to me.)  All systems have their merits and their drawbacks. ¬†It's knowing how to make the most of the system you're in that matters.

porcupineracer2 have you ever looked in to a resource-based economy, a holistic social and economic system in which the planetary resources are held as the common heritage of all the earth's inhabitants. The current practice of rationing resources through monetary methods is irrelevant, counter-productive, and falls far short of meeting humanity's needs. Simply stated, within a Resource Based Economy we will utilize existing resources - rather than money - to provide an equitable method of distribution in the most humane and efficient manner. It is a system in which all goods and services are available to everyone without the use of money, credits, barter, or any other form of debt or servitude. To better understand a resource-based economy, consider this. If all the money in the world disappeared overnight, as long as topsoil, factories, personnel and other resources were left intact, we could build anything we needed to fulfill most human needs. It is not money that people require, but rather free access to most of their needs without worrying about financial security or having to appeal to a government bureaucracy. In a resource-based economy of abundance, money will become irrelevant. We have arrived at a time when new innovations in science and technology can easily provide abundance to all of the world's people. It is no longer necessary to perpetuate the conscious withdrawal of efficiency by planned obsolescence, perpetuated by our old and outworn profit system. If we are genuinely concerned about the environment and our fellow human beings, if we really want to end territorial disputes, war, crime, poverty and hunger, we must consciously reconsider the social processes that led us to a world where these factors are common. Like it or not, it is our social processes - political practices, belief systems, profit-based economy, our culture-driven behavioral norms - that lead to and support hunger, war, disease and environmental damage. The aim of this new social design is to encourage an incentive system no longer directed toward the shallow and self-centered goals of wealth, property, and power. These new incentives would encourage people toward self-fulfillment and creativity, both materially and spiritually.

There's no income increase for the employed even if businesses have increases in profits...which stifle demand. And the same useless cycle continue to widen the gap of income inequality and the economy can suffer. The need is for businesses not only to hire people when needed...but to pay well also...because that is what creates the demand that makes all the businesses work. *****¬† Sadly, this is a broad generalization and villianization of leasing landowners that is in most cases patently false. I don't know where you live, but one neighborhood/city/county is not representative of a populace.¬†  My father came to inherit his grandmother's home which is next door to house we occupy at the moment. The home is old, and was apart of his childhood, and he thinks selling it would be an insult to her memory -- but he can't let it sit empty. Five tenants have come through that house in the ten years its been leased, and each has done more damage to the house than good -- he charged $400 a month starting out, a three bedroom, two bath home with full appliances and an internal well -- only utility is electricity.  The first tenant when moving out, ripped nails and screws from the wall paneling, flipped the dryer and left it in the living room and took a sledge hammer to the refrigerators door. Before we could file charges the family of five had fled the state.  Next tenant he raised the rent to $600, hoping to keep it from happening again. This tenant painted one of the bed rooms the ugliest shade of teal you can think of, and scattered popcorn kernals (unpopped) throughout the house, neglected the air conditioner, broke two ceiling fans moving out, terminated the electric bill before her rent ended, and destroyed the yard by driving her boyfriend's pick up through it after slashing the tires. We were able to press charges against her, but we didn't receive anything as she attempted to murder her son and her boyfriend before pleading insanity.  Finally, my father was reaching the point in which he was about to sell the home before I convinced him to let me attempt handling the lease. My first term was first and last month's rent ($1,200), and the Security of $1,000 up front.  Three tenants have passed through the house in the course of my 6 year tenure of being a 'Landlord'. All amenable, accepting of my terms, and generally friendly people. With the rate we've finally had the funds to make ends meet in our home as well as make improvements to the rent property. Our latest tenants -- a family of four -- even helped us to construct a ramp on the front porch, remodel the Car port, re-landscape the yard, and replace the remaining appliances which were coming to the age 40 years running.¬†  Next time you think your Landlord is screwing you, think of how you've treated the property he's agreed to let you use, think of how people have screwed him before, and more importantly; get your head out of your ass.  On to the actual topic of this documentary:  While it makes no direct political statements, it does create an unease about the current state of affairs concerning the treatment of the Lower and Middle Class by the System and the Upper Class. It does a great job of informing you of the realities of the fact that just about anyone can fall to the breaking point and the challenges of treading water with $100,000 dollars in lead tied to your ankles.  But the question really is -- what is the realistic way to fix this? What can you do when you're at the bottom with the rest crushing down on you without discarding your morals? What will it take to change this -- will anything really change this? If you think you know it, ask why it isn't already happening (you are not the genius you think you are -- unless you've got something mind blowingly complex)?  The Solution isn't quick, its not easy, and it certainly not going to be entirely bloodless or utter rebellion.

Agreed to the original comment. Cheques of checks seem very outdated to some Europeans like me (never used them). In Holland and Germany I think we stopped we using them 15 years ago. However they are still used a lot in most of the world including most of southern Europe (France / italy) etc. So the countries that do not use them are a very small minority.

This euro can't really recall people paying stuff with checks over here. However I did spend a year in the States '99-'00 and got acquainted with them. I thankfully had my Visa Electron with me back then, which I could use to draw funds from my Finnish account, and got a local bank account with an atm card as well. I deposited my monthly check (50 bucks) into my US account. So didn't handle checks all that much, but saw other people using them and balancing their checkbooks quite often.  In the very early nineties I did have an 'account book', but pretty soon it was all cards and monthly statements via mail. My very first rents I paid via a payment atm, but since at least 2002 I've used internet banking for those. My employee deposits my wage minus taxes directly onto my account, so that it is available to me by the last of each month. One's credit is fine, if they've paid their bills (rent, electricity etc. on time) and have a steady monthly income. I use the credit option of my debit/credit card for some online shopping, but not much else as I can plan my finances pretty well based on my income. However it is nice to have the option to use it, if something bad suddenly happens and my insurance company can't react instantly.
